.@_OlivierGiroud_ is our feature interview in this month's Chelsea magazine! It's out now! 👉
https://beta.chelseafc.com/en/news/2018/5/14/giroud-giving-everything-in-new-mag

Chelsea failings will cost them more than just £9.5m bill for Antonio Conte

When the Chelsea hierarchy meet to discuss who is responsible for the club’s failure to qualify for the Champions League, they should take a long look in the mirror.

Putting their poor transfer business to one side, the board’s passive approach toward coach Antonio Conte means they already have to take a fair share of the blame.

Under owner Roman Abramovich, Chelsea have a reputation for being ruthless when their place in Europe’s premier club competition is under threat.

Jose Mourinho, Luiz Felipe Scolari, Andre Villas-Boas and Roberto Di Matteo were axed after a campaign started to go badly wrong.

This season’s unlikely bid to finish in the top four came to an appropriate end on Sunday when they surrendered meekly to Newcastle, losing 3-0.

It seemed fitting that the man orchestrating their downfall was Rafael Benitez, a former interim manager at Stamford Bridge who salvaged 2012-13 by securing third place in the table as well as the Europa League trophy.

Indeed, on four of the five occasions the Blues made a change in the dug-out mid-season, it had a positive impact.

In 2007-8, under Avram Grant, they reached their first Champions League Final and were runners-up in the top flight; in 2008-9, Guus Hiddink took them to third, a Champions League semi-final and the FA Cup while in 2011-12 Di Matteo lifted the European Cup and FA Cup. The trick only failed in 2015-16, but given Chelsea were one point off the bottom three when Hiddink replaced Mourinho before Christmas, the downturn was too great and they finished 10th.

Chelsea’s display at St James’ Park rivalled other capitulations against lesser opposition this term, like the 4-1 demolition at Watford. Yet despite how dire things looked at Vicarage Road in February, Chelsea were still fourth with 12 League fixtures remaining and in a position where a new appointment could still make a difference.


Conte had clearly stopped being effective or able to inspire his players on a regular basis several months ago.

But when many fans expected the club to make a change, the club chose a policy of appeasement instead.

With Conte understandably refusing to resign, Chelsea allowed things to fester. Some will argue it was a sign of the powers that be backing their man but given relations have been strained since pre-season, it felt more a case of not wanting to give the former Juventus coach money for nothing.

Two months after the Watford debacle, they were 10 points behind rivals Tottenham and Liverpool in fifth.

It’s worth noting that Chelsea changed their compensation policy after Scolari and his staff were paid a lump sum of £42m in 2009. After that, axed coaches have been given their weekly salary only until they have found employment elsewhere.

There have been suggestions that Conte is prepared to take a sabbatical from the game, if handed a P45, in order to receive the £9.5m owing on the final year of his contract.

But even if that is the case, that’s a cheap price to pay given the winners of the Champions League next year stand to make in excess of £100m. In contrast, Manchester United claimed only £40m for lifting the Europa League— the competition Chelsea have now dropped into - 12 months ago.

As usual, Conte explained after the Newcastle defeat, it was up to Chelsea to decide whether he stays. He said: “I am committed for this club. The most important thing is what the club thinks, not you or the speculation.”

Chelsea must pay off eight of Antonio Conte's loyal backroom staff if under-fire manager is sacked this summer

The cost of sacking Antonio Conte is being forced up and the task complicated by the prospect of removing and replacing the army of staff he has built around him at Chelsea.

A total of nine Italians will go if Conte leaves Stamford Bridge as expected after Saturday's FA Cup final against Manchester United.

Napoli boss Maurizio Sarri has emerged as the leading candidate to succeed him.

Conte, who has one year left on his £9million-a-year contract, brought in six staff when he arrived in 2016.

And when Steve Holland left to become Gareth Southgate's assistant with England last year, Conte was allowed to bring in another two.

This was Roman Abramovich's attempt to back a manager who impressed as he won the title in his first season.

The Russian owner had been stung by this in the past, with enormous pay-offs for Jose Mourinho and his staff in 2007 and then for Luiz Felipe Scolari and his assistants in 2009.

Chelsea tried to scale back on itinerant staff when Carlo Ancelotti arrived in 2009 by bringing in Ray Wilkins and Holland, and promoting Paul Clement.

SKY SOURCES: Chelsea considering making a move for Mauricio Pochettino if Antonio Conte leaves club. #SSN

Plenty to blame for Chelsea malaise, but none more than sulking Antonio Conte

Chelsea players themselves have to take responsibility for lacklustre displays and defeats by Bournemouth (3-0), Watford (4-1) and Newcastle United (3-0), when they swapped the blue flag for the white one. They have a professional duty to the club, the shirt and the support, let alone personal pride, and failed badly. They let the fans down.

Fans were also let down this season by Abramovich, Marina Granovskaia and Bruce Buck, those responsible for the culture of the club, the inherent uncertainty built into the manager’s job, inconsistent recruiting and not being more assertive in demanding that youth-team talent was given a chance.

But the greatest frustration for Chelsea fans has been Antonio Conte. He has been the big problem this season, the individual who should be most embarrassed, the erstwhile galvanising force who became the moody Blue. Conte didn’t get the players he wanted, so behaved as if in a sulk. There is still plenty of ability in that squad, and the group he inherited he guided to the title. Maybe Conte is not the same without Steve Holland.

Chelsea fans remain loyal to Conte, just about, even if they regularly take to social media to highlight his calamitous mistakes — the six changes against Huddersfield and particularly starting with Hazard and Olivier Giroud on the bench. And why drop Antonio Rüdiger against Newcastle?

They have always sung passionately about Conte but this is a love at risk of souring. They adored his animation, but at St James’ Park on Sunday Conte was cold and undemonstrative. Champions League qualification on the final day was always going to be a tough, demanding ask post-Huddersfield, but at least give it a go. Chelsea didn’t. Conte sets the mood and the mood was unresponsive and defeatist.

Conte was also responsible for the text that so alienated Diego Costa, a move proving even more damaging now. Chelsea miss Costa badly.

It is so sad that such a charismatic soul has become an empty vessel, bereft of ideas and energy, setting slow sail down the Thames and eventually back to Italy. Conte may yet recover his reputation and find a way to set Chelsea up tactically and emotionally to deal with Manchester United at Wembley. He may yet devise a masterplan to thwart José Mourinho, who relishes these big occasions.

If Conte does, and admittedly the odds are against, Chelsea fans will be left wondering why he didn’t do this in the league. And, if Chelsea lose to Mourinho, the fans’ frustration will surely be replaced with bitterness.

Real Madrid are ready to test Chelsea’s resolve to hang on to goalkeeper Thibaut Courtois when the summer transfer window opens.

The Belgium international declared recently he would still be at Chelsea next season, although he has still to put pen to paper on a new contract, but a report in The Mirror claims Los Blancos are ready to take him back to Spain following his time with Atletico Madrid.

Madrid supremo Florentino Perez is understood to be keen to replace Keylor Navas, and having seemingly given up on trying to prise David de Gea away from Manchester United, he has now turned his sights to Courtois, who still has 12 months left on his current agreement at Stamford Bridge.

The Londoners have failed to qualify for the Champions League and the player is understood to look favourably on a move to the Santiago Bernabeu, given his former partner lives in the Spanish capital with his son and daughter.

車路士周六晚會喺足總盃決賽同曼聯爭奪冠軍，車仔著名粉絲、由Model轉行做體育記者嘅靚女Amy，賽前就炮轟愛隊近期立立亂，準備放棄去睇呢場決賽，改為參加英國皇室婚禮街頭派對喎！Amy向英國《太陽報》表示：「我覺得就算車路士拎到足總盃冠軍，今季喺阿布拉莫域眼中都係一個好失敗嘅球季，考慮到干地隊波近期踢出嘅水平，同埋球隊內部種種問題，我正考慮賣咗足總盃決賽嘅波飛，去參加皇室婚禮街頭派對算數。」

對於有傳車路士想搵普捷天奴執教，Amy同樣唔讚成，佢話：「我唔否認普捷天奴教熱刺教得好好，不過佢從來未贏過聯賽或者任何賽事冠軍，而阿布拉莫域係一個視成績大過一切嘅人，而且以車路士嘅架構，普捷天奴都唔會想過嚟，除非佢真係好憎熱刺，憎到好似車路士球迷討厭韋利安咁啦！」

quote.msg: Conte on giving back to fans the trophy after a bad league run: "I don't know about this. For sure, I can tell you in this season we worked harder than last season, I am sure about this. For me, that's enough for myself."

【now.com體育】車路士於周六英足盃決賽硬撼曼聯，名宿林柏特賽前就譏笑紅魔中場保羅普巴是「YouTube球員」。

曾為車路士贏過4次英足盃的林柏特（Frank Lampard）說：「我不知道保羅普巴是甚麼，他經常都作出錯誤決定，多於交出精采表現，這一定令領隊摩連奴很頭痕。摩佬嘗試過令普巴尷尬去教訓他，但我擔心普巴並不明白。」

摩連奴在2016年從祖雲達斯買入普巴，很明顯希望複製當年於車路士的成功方程式，以這名法國國腳出任林柏特的角色。

踢法向來實際的林伯表示：「普巴的天份比我高，而且跑得比我快，技術亦比我好，但在自己後半場運球是沒有意思的。所有挑挑剔剔的花巧，我從來都不主張，很多年輕球員在YouTube看到，認為這很神奇，但我完全不喜歡。」
